parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts increases soil organic carbon levels and organic matter content.
[Statement 3]: Studies found higher carbon levels in soil when manures were applied.
[Statement 4]: Using crops grown as green manures results in higher soil organic carbon.
[Statement 5]: Amending soil using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments leads to more organic carbon in soils.
[Statement 6]: Four controlled trials found more organic carbon in soils with mixed fertilizers.
[Statement 7]: Manure alone also increases organic carbon in soils.
[Statement 8]: Changing tillage practices significantly impacts soil organic matter.
[Statement 9]: Twelve studies found higher soil organic carbon in soils under no-tillage or reduced tillage systems compared to conventionally tilled soil.
[Statement 10]: Eight studies found that reduced tillage maintained or increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 11]: Reducing tillage provides benefits for soil organic matter retention.
[Statement 12]: Retaining crop residues increases soil organic carbon and nitrogen.
[Statement 13]: Two randomized trials found higher soil organic carbon when crop residues were retained.
[Statement 14]: Incorporating plant remains into soil contributes to soil organic matter through the addition of organic materials.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms.
[Statement 2]: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use is highly effective for increasing the diversity of soil organisms.
[Statement 3]: Low-input systems have a higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.
[Statement 4]: Converting to organic farming shows significant benefits for soil organisms.
[Statement 5]: Soil organisms have higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity under organic management.
[Statement 6]: Tillage management practices are particularly important for soil organism diversity.
[Statement 7]: No-tillage cultivation methods result in more microbial biomass and more earthworms.
[Statement 8]: No-tillage cultivation methods result in different communities of nematodes and mites.
[Statement 9]: Reduced tillage practices increase microbial biomass and earthworms.
[Statement 10]: Using crop rotation increases the number of microbes and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 11]: Including legumes in crop rotation increases the number of microbes and the diversity of different soil animals.
[Statement 12]: Cover crop management provides substantial benefits for soil organisms.
[Statement 13]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty results in more diverse nematode communities.
[Statement 14]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty results in greater microbial biomass.
[Statement 15]: Using cover crops or ground cover in perennial crops increases microbial biomass, symbiotic fungi, bacteria and nematodes.
[Statement 16]: Adding mulch to crops increases soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity and activity.
[Statement 17]: Soil amendments directly support soil organism diversity.
[Statement 18]: Amending soil with bacteria or fungi results in higher microbial diversity.
[Statement 19]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains to soil increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 20]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments leads to higher microbial biomass, activity and diversity.
[Statement 21]: Alley cropping results in a higher diversity of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi.
[Statement 22]: Excluding grazers from areas results in more nematodes.
[Statement 23]: Excluding grazers from areas results in more diverse nematode communities.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Soil amendments with different types of organic materials have been shown to produce various beneficial effects.
[Statement 2]: Organic processing wastes and their composts improved soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Organic processing wastes and their composts reduced soil loss.
[Statement 4]: Organic processing wastes and their composts increased nutrient loss when applied at high rates.
[Statement 5]: Adding molasses to organic processing wastes and their composts improved nutrient retention.
[Statement 6]: Adding molasses to organic processing wastes and their composts increased barley yields.
[Statement 7]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 8]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments reduced soil cracking more effectively than inorganic fertilizers alone.
[Statement 9]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased soil organic carbon content.
[Statement 10]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments enhanced soil nutrients.
[Statement 11]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased maize yields.
[Statement 12]: General composts applied at high rates increased soil organic matter levels.
[Statement 13]: General composts applied at high rates increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 14]: General composts applied at high rates increased fruit yield.
[Statement 15]: Manures and agricultural composts consistently increased microbial biomass and respiration.
[Statement 16]: Manures and agricultural composts reduced soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 17]: Manures and agricultural composts reduced nutrient loss.
[Statement 18]: Manures and agricultural composts increased nitrogen levels.
[Statement 19]: Manures and agricultural composts increased soil carbon levels.
[Statement 20]: Manures and agricultural composts improved soil physical properties, including creating larger soil aggregations.
[Statement 21]: Manures and agricultural composts increased crop yields.
[Statement 22]: Green manures increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 23]: Green manures increased grain yields.
[Statement 24]: Fresh plant material and crop remains increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 25]: Fresh plant material and crop remains improved soil structure.
[Statement 26]: Fresh plant material and crop remains reduced soil loss, with mixed effects depending on soil type.
[Statement 27]: Fresh plant material and crop remains increased soil nitrogen levels.
[Statement 28]: Fresh plant material and crop remains reduced nitrate leaching.
[Statement 29]: Fresh plant material and crop remains consistently increased soil carbon levels.
[Statement 30]: Fresh plant material and crop remains created larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 31]: Fresh plant material and crop remains improved crop yields.
[Statement 32]: Charcoal amendments showed minimal effects on plant biomass.
[Statement 33]: Charcoal amendments showed minimal effects on grass cover.
[Statement 34]: Charcoal amendments increased legume cover.
[Statement 35]: Non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes reduced nutrient loss.
[Statement 36]: Non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes reduced erosion.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Besides retaining crop residues, several actions can effectively reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils.
[Statement 2]: Changing tillage practices shows significant benefits for reducing soil erosion.
[Statement 3]: Reduced tillage lessens soil loss and runoff when compared to conventional ploughing.
[Statement 4]: Adding mulch to crops reduces soil erosion and runoff.
[Statement 5]: Mulches increase soil stability and reduce soil erosion.
[Statement 6]: Growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows reduces erosion.
[Statement 7]: Crop rotation that includes legumes reduces rainwater runoff and soil loss.
[Statement 8]: Crop rotation that includes legumes increases water infiltration into the soil.
[Statement 9]: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains reduces soil loss.
[Statement 10]: The effects of amending soil with fresh plant material can vary depending on soil type.
[Statement 11]: Amending soil using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments is more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than using inorganic fertilizers alone.
[Statement 12]: Controlled traffic on agricultural land reduces runoff.
[Statement 13]: Controlled traffic on agricultural land increases water filtration into the soil.
[Statement 14]: Reducing grazing intensity, by reducing grazing time in forage crops, reduces sediment erosion.
[Statement 15]: Planting new hedges reduces soil erosion.
[Statement 16]: Planting new hedges increases soil organic matter levels.
[Statement 17]: Providing un-harvested buffer strips can contribute to soil protection on agricultural land.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Besides retaining crop residues, what other actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on evidence from controlled trials in Asian countries, several soil amendments are effective for improving crop yields on farms.
[Statement 2]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments demonstrated increased maize yields in controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China.
[Statement 3]: Green manures showed effectiveness in studies from India and Pakistan, which found increased grain yields when green manures were grown.
[Statement 4]: Fresh plant material and crop remains showed benefits for crop yields.
[Statement 5]: One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
[Statement 6]: Bacterial and fungal amendments showed promise for improving crop yields.
[Statement 7]: Randomized, replicated trials from India and Turkey found higher crop yields when soil bacteria and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi were added.
[Statement 8]: Manures and agricultural composts demonstrated effectiveness in controlled, replicated studies from India, Spain and Turkey that found higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied.
[Statement 9]: One study showed higher crop yields when manure was applied in combination with cover crops.
[Statement 10]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased soil organic carbon in studies from China and India.
[Statement 11]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments improved soil microbial biomass and activity in trials from China, India and Japan.
[Statement 12]: Green manures increased soil organic carbon in studies from India and Pakistan.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different soil amendments for improving crop yields on farms in Asia?
_claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils.
[Statement 2]: Cover crops are highly effective for reducing nitrate losses.
[Statement 3]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure and nutrient retention.
[Statement 4]: Studies have found that growing cover crops when fields are empty leads to reduced nitrate leaching.
[Statement 5]: Less nitrate was leached from soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without winter cover crops.
[Statement 6]: Growing cover crops beneath main crops or between crop rows helps retain nutrients.
[Statement 7]: Chemical amendments can reduce nitrate losses.
[Statement 8]: Nitrification inhibitors applied to soil can reduce nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions.
[Statement 9]: The method of application for nitrification inhibitors influences the inhibitors' effectiveness.
[Statement 10]: Timing management strategies are important for reducing nutrient loss.
[Statement 11]: Delaying ploughing until spring reduces nitrate leaching compared to autumn ploughing.
[Statement 12]: Organic amendments help with nutrient retention.
[Statement 13]: The application of farmyard or poultry manure can lead to reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels.
[Statement 14]: Applying farmyard manure in winter can result in lower nutrient loss compared to applying the manure in autumn.
[Statement 15]: Using organic fertilizers rather than mineral fertilizers supports better nutrient management.
[Statement 16]: Buffer strips provide protection against nutrient runoff.
[Statement 17]: Irrigated pastures with buffer strips had less nitrate in their runoff compared to irrigated pastures without buffer strips.
[Statement 18]: Buffer strips increase nitrogen retention in soils.
[Statement 19]: Buffer strips reduce pesticide and nutrient runoff into waterways.
[Statement 20]: Reducing chemical inputs in grassland management helps prevent excess nutrient loss.
[Statement 21]: Reducing chemical inputs in grassland management helps maintain soil health.

[Statement 1]: Several agricultural practices consistently provide benefits for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: Four studies found higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity, or activity of soil organisms under organic management.
[Statement 3]: Two replicated trials showed organically managed orchards had higher soil carbon levels.
[Statement 4]: Twelve studies found higher soil organic carbon in soils under no-tillage or reduced tillage systems.
[Statement 5]: Four of eleven studies that measured effects on soil biodiversity found more microbes, more earthworm species, or higher microbe activity under reduced tillage.
[Statement 6]: Four studies found increased soil organic carbon under crop rotation, particularly when legumes were included.
[Statement 7]: Four randomized replicated trials found that including legumes in crop rotations increased the number of microbes and diversity of soil animals.
[Statement 8]: Growing cover crops resulted in increased soil carbon levels according to one replicated study and one review.
[Statement 9]: One controlled randomized replicated experiment found more diverse nematode communities as a result of growing cover crops.
[Statement 10]: One replicated trial found greater microbial biomass from growing cover crops.
[Statement 11]: Three replicated trials found that adding mulch to crops increased soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity and activity.
[Statement 12]: One trial found that adding mulch to crops also increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 13]: Three controlled replicated studies found higher microbial biomass when manure or agricultural compost was applied to soil.
[Statement 14]: Four studies found higher carbon levels when manures were applied to soil.
[Statement 15]: One replicated study found higher microbial biomass when crop residues were retained.
[Statement 16]: Two randomized replicated trials found higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen when crop residues were retained.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which actions are most consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity?
_claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to adding compost, what other actions can improve the soil structure of silty-clay soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to compost can improve soil structure in silty-clay soils.
[Statement 2]: Tillage modifications are effective at improving soil structure in silty-clay soils.
[Statement 3]: Changing tillage practices to reduced or no-till systems can improve soil structure and increase soil organic matter in silty-clay soils.
[Statement 4]: No-tillage systems create more large aggregates and higher water-stability compared to reduced tillage.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage in arable fields increases organic matter compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 6]: Reduced tillage in arable fields improves soil aggregation with higher water-stability compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 7]: Traffic management through controlling traffic and timing reduces soil compaction and increases soil porosity.
[Statement 8]: In silty-clay soils, traffic management has shown benefits including reduced soil crack width and improved water filtration.
[Statement 9]: Mixing organic and inorganic amendments is more effective at reducing cracks in dry soil than using inorganic fertilizers alone.
[Statement 10]: Adding non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes to soil reduces nutrient loss and erosion.
[Statement 11]: Adding gypsum to soil can improve soil conditions, though limited evidence is available.
[Statement 12]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 13]: Growing cover crops increases soil porosity and interconnectivity, and reduces soil resistance.
[Statement 14]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains, such as incorporated straw, improves soil structure.
[Statement 15]: Adding fresh plant material or crop remains increases carbon levels and creates larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 16]: Retaining crop residues increases soil organic carbon and nitrogen.
[Statement 17]: Retaining crop residues improves soil physical properties including aggregate size.

[Statement 1]: Several organic soil management practices have been shown to be effective alternatives to chemical fertilizers for increasing crop yield.
[Statement 2]: Organic fertilizers including manures and agricultural composts have demonstrated positive effects.
[Statement 3]: Studies from India, Spain, and Turkey found higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied.
[Statement 4]: Studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found higher crop yields in plots with added compost compared to plots without added compost.
[Statement 5]: Green manures and crop residue management are effective organic soil management practices.
[Statement 6]: Studies from India and Pakistan found increased grain yields when green manures were grown.
[Statement 7]: Retaining crop residues showed beneficial effects on crop yields.
[Statement 8]: Trials from Australia and China found higher yields when crop residues were retained.
[Statement 9]: Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains increased yields in trials from Denmark and the Philippines.
[Statement 10]: Organic processing wastes and their composts have shown promise for increasing crop yield.
[Statement 11]: One trial found that adding molasses increased barley yield.
[Statement 12]: The use of organic rather than mineral fertilizers generally supports higher plant diversity.
[Statement 13]: The use of organic rather than mineral fertilizers generally supports improved soil biological activity.
[Statement 14]: Converting to organic farming showed mixed results for yields.
[Statement 15]: Converting to organic farming demonstrated higher soil carbon levels in some cases.
[Statement 16]: Converting to organic farming demonstrated improved fruit quality and disease resistance in some cases.
[Statement 17]: Mixed approaches combining organic and inorganic amendments have also proven effective.
[Statement 18]: Trials from China found increased maize yield in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments.
[Statement 19]: Cover crops provide the additional benefit of reducing nutrient leaching.
[Statement 20]: Cover crops provide the additional benefit of improving water management.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to using chemical fertilizers to increase crop yield, what organic soil management practices are shown to be effective?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction.
[Statement 2]: Changing tillage practices is an effective method for improving soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Studies show that reduced tillage and no-tillage systems can reduce soil compaction.
[Statement 4]: Controlled traffic and reduced tillage were found in five studies to reduce compaction.
[Statement 5]: Controlled traffic and reduced tillage led to subsequent effects like reduced water runoff.
[Statement 6]: Crop yields increased under no-tillage systems.
[Statement 7]: No-tillage systems showed more large aggregates in soils when compared to reduced tillage systems.
[Statement 8]: No-tillage systems showed higher water-stability in soils in some comparisons with reduced tillage.
[Statement 9]: Controlling traffic and the timing of traffic helps reduce soil compaction.
[Statement 10]: Five trials found less compaction, reduced runoff, and increased water filtration into the soil under controlled traffic.
[Statement 11]: Adding organic matter by incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains improves soil structure.
[Statement 12]: One study found that soil structure improved when straw was incorporated into the soil.
[Statement 13]: Growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows reduces erosion.
[Statement 14]: Growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows improves soil structure.
[Statement 15]: Studies showed reduced erosion and the highest soil stability under grass cover.
[Statement 16]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 17]: Three studies found that cover crops improved soil structure, leading to higher soil porosity and interconnectivity.
[Statement 18]: Three studies found that cover crops improved soil structure, leading to lower resistance in the soil.
[Statement 19]: Using crop rotation helps improve soil conditions.
[Statement 20]: Studies showed that including forage crops in rotation reduced rainwater runoff and soil loss.
[Statement 21]: Studies showed that including legumes in rotation increased water infiltration.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can improve soil structure by reducing compaction?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The available evidence on soil amendments affecting biodiversity in sandy loam texture soils comes from several controlled studies.
[Statement 2]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments show increased microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 3]: One trial found that mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased microbial diversity.
[Statement 4]: The trial on mixed organic and inorganic amendments specifically covered sandy-loam soil types among others.
[Statement 5]: Amendments of fresh plant material or crop remains result in increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw are added.
[Statement 6]: The finding that fresh plant material or crop remains increase microbial biomass is based on a randomized, replicated experiment.
[Statement 7]: The experiment on fresh plant material and crop remains covered sandy loam soil types.
[Statement 8]: Bacterial and fungal amendments lead to higher microbial diversity in one randomized, replicated trial.
[Statement 9]: The trial on bacterial and fungal amendments covered sandy-loam soil types.
[Statement 10]: Manures and agricultural composts produce higher microbial biomass when poultry manure is applied.
[Statement 11]: Manures and agricultural composts produce higher microbial respiration when poultry manure is applied.
[Statement 12]: The findings on poultry manure are according to three controlled, replicated studies.
[Statement 13]: The studies on manures and agricultural composts covered sandy loam and sandy clay loam soil types.
[Statement 14]: Organic processing waste composts applied at high rates improve soil structure according to controlled, replicated trials.
[Statement 15]: The trials on organic processing waste composts covered sandy loam soil types.
[Statement 16]: General compost applications increase microbial biomass, a finding based on one controlled, randomized, replicated trial.
[Statement 17]: The trial on general compost applications specifically covered silty-clay soil types.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the available evidence on how different soil amendments affect biodiversity in soils with a sandy loam texture?
_claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to adding mulch, what actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Alternatives to mulching can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils.
[Statement 2]: Retaining crop residues reduces water runoff, increases water storage, and reduces soil erosion on sandy-loam soils.
[Statement 3]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty improves soil structure and nutrient retention.
[Statement 4]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty increases soil carbon levels and is effective on sandy clay and sandy-loam soils.
[Statement 5]: Living mulches or cover crops grown between crop rows reduce erosion on sandy and sandy loam soils.
[Statement 6]: Living mulches or cover crops grown between crop rows increase soil organic matter on sandy and sandy loam soils.
[Statement 7]: Manures and agricultural composts can increase soil organic matter and improve soil physical properties.
[Statement 8]: Manures and agricultural composts can reduce soil loss and water runoff on sandy loam and sandy clay loam soils.
[Statement 9]: Organic processing wastes and composts made from organic processing wastes improve soil structure and reduce soil loss on sandy-clay and sandy loam soils.
[Statement 10]: Non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes reduce nutrient loss and erosion on sandy clay soils.
[Statement 11]: Bacterial and fungal amendments increase soil organic matter content and are effective on sandy-loam soils.
[Statement 12]: Changing tillage practices to no-tillage or reduced tillage systems increases soil organic carbon and organic matter content.
[Statement 13]: No-tillage and reduced tillage systems result in higher soil water content and improved water absorption on various soil types including sandy and sandy loam soils.
[Statement 14]: Chemical soil amendments with fertilizers increase soil organic matter and carbon.
[Statement 15]: Chemical soil amendments with fertilizers are particularly effective on loamy sand and sandy loam soils.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the wider soil health effects of amending soils with animal-derived products like manure or composts?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Animal-derived soil amendments like manure and composts have multiple positive effects on soil health.
[Statement 2]: Microbial biomass and activity increase when manure and agricultural composts are applied.
[Statement 3]: The application of manure and agricultural composts can increase microbial diversity.
[Statement 4]: Soil organic carbon levels are enhanced by manure applications.
[Statement 5]: Multiple studies found higher carbon levels when manures were applied.
[Statement 6]: Applying manure and compost increases soil organic matter content.
[Statement 7]: Applying manure and compost can lead to larger soil aggregations.
[Statement 8]: Applying manure and compost has positive effects on soil physical properties.
[Statement 9]: Applying high rates of compost increases soil organic matter levels.
[Statement 10]: Applying high rates of compost increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 11]: Applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure can improve soil structure.
[Statement 12]: Mixed organic and inorganic amendments were more effective at reducing crack formation in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone.
[Statement 13]: Applying farmyard or poultry manure can reduce nutrient loss.
[Statement 14]: Applying farmyard or poultry manure can result in higher nitrogen levels.
[Statement 15]: High application rates of amendments can increase nutrient loss.
[Statement 16]: Manure application can result in lower soil loss.
[Statement 17]: Manure application can result in lower water runoff.
[Statement 18]: Multiple controlled studies found higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied.
[Statement 19]: Mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments can increase maize yield.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of converting to low-input or organic farming systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Converting to low-input or organic farming systems shows mixed benefits and drawbacks across different agricultural outcomes.
[Statement 2]: Biodiversity improvements were found in multiple studies of low-input or organic farming systems.
[Statement 3]: Organic farming supported more natural enemies in a majority of studies, though effects varied over time and between species.
[Statement 4]: Wild bee abundance was higher under organic arable farming in replicated trials in Europe and Canada.
[Statement 5]: One study showed higher bee diversity in organically farmed wheat fields.
[Statement 6]: Higher overall bat activity was found on organic farms compared to non-organic farms in studies across Europe, the USA, Canada, and Chile.
[Statement 7]: Reduced chemical inputs in grasslands resulted in increased plant species richness and reduced plant species loss rates in studies from the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the UK.
[Statement 8]: Reduced chemical inputs in grasslands attracted a higher abundance or species richness of invertebrates in studies from the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the UK.
[Statement 9]: Low-input systems showed a higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in studies from Italy and Pakistan.
[Statement 10]: Reducing chemical inputs benefited some invertebrates, plants, or farmland birds in the vast majority of individual studies from across Europe.
[Statement 11]: The yield and economic impacts of converting to low-input or organic farming showed mixed results.
[Statement 12]: Net profit from low-input or organic farming increased only if the produce received a premium.
[Statement 13]: Net profit from low-input or organic farming decreased if the produce did not receive a premium.
[Statement 14]: Pest and disease management showed challenges under organic farming.
[Statement 15]: Only a minority of studies found reduced pests or disease under organic farming, while some studies found more pests.
[Statement 16]: Weed management presented difficulties in low-input or organic farming systems.
[Statement 17]: Multiple randomized controlled studies found more weeds in organically farmed fields.
[Statement 18]: Lower nutrient levels and yields were found in low-input systems in studies from Canada.
[Statement 19]: Some studies found negative or no effects on invertebrates, plants, or birds when reducing chemical inputs.

[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to conventional ploughing in Europe can improve soil structure.
[Statement 2]: No-tillage systems show significant benefits for soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Studies from Mediterranean countries including Italy, Spain, and Portugal found that no-tillage increased organic matter in soils compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 4]: No-tillage systems led to more stable soil aggregates.
[Statement 5]: No-tillage systems led to reduced erosion.
[Statement 6]: Studies from Spain and the USA found that soils without tillage were more stable than tilled soils.
[Statement 7]: No-tillage systems increased earthworm populations.
[Statement 8]: Studies from the USA found more earthworms in soils without tillage compared to soils with tillage.
[Statement 9]: Reduced tillage systems provide soil structure improvements.
[Statement 10]: A meta-analysis from multiple Mediterranean countries found more organic matter in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 11]: Studies from Italy, Spain, Syria, and the USA found more organic matter in soils with reduced tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 12]: Reduced tillage systems showed improved soil aggregation.
[Statement 13]: Studies from Spain found that soil aggregates had higher water-stability in plots with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 14]: The broader category of changing tillage practices demonstrates various benefits.
[Statement 15]: Studies from Canada, Europe, Mexico, and the USA found that reduced tillage led to higher soil organic carbon compared to conventionally tilled soil.
[Statement 16]: Fifteen studies from Canada, China, Europe, Morocco, and the USA found that reduced tillage maintained or increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 17]: Fifteen studies from Canada, China, Europe, Morocco, and the USA found that reduced tillage improved soil structure.
[Statement 18]: Four trials found higher nutrient retention under reduced tillage.
[Statement 19]: Studies found more species of earthworms under reduced tillage compared to conventional systems.
[Statement 20]: Studies found higher microbe activity under reduced tillage compared to conventional systems.
[Statement 21]: Tillage alternatives were tested across various European soil types.
[Statement 22]: The European soil types tested include calcareous silt loam, chalky, clay, clay loam, fine sandy loam, loam, loamy-clay, sandy loam, silt loam, silty, and silty clay loam soils.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In Europe, what alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several practices have been shown to increase soil microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with composts increases soil organic matter levels and microbial biomass.
[Statement 3]: Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts results in higher microbial biomass.
[Statement 4]: Soils with reduced tillage have been found to have more microbial biomass compared to soils with conventional tillage in some comparisons.
[Statement 5]: Converting to organic farming increases the numbers of soil organisms.
[Statement 6]: Converting to organic farming increases the diversity of soil organisms.
[Statement 7]: Converting to organic farming increases the functional diversity or activity of soil organisms.
[Statement 8]: Growing cover crops when fields are empty increases microbial biomass.
[Statement 9]: One replicated trial found greater microbial biomass under ryegrass compared to a ryegrass/vetch cover crop mix.
[Statement 10]: Including legumes in crop rotation can increase microbial biomass.
[Statement 11]: Soils with crop rotations were found to have more microbial biomass compared to continuous crops in some comparisons.
[Statement 12]: Including legumes in crop rotations increases the number of microbes.
[Statement 13]: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally benefits soil microorganisms.
[Statement 14]: Studies have found a higher diversity of microorganisms in low-input systems.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which actions are most effective for increasing soil microbial biomass?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are some of the most effective actions for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several effective techniques have been identified for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land.
[Statement 2]: Cover crops grown beneath main crops or between crop rows have shown significant effectiveness in reducing erosion and soil loss.
[Statement 3]: Cover crops can increase soil stability.
[Statement 4]: Adding mulch to crops is a highly effective method for reducing soil erosion and runoff.
[Statement 5]: Mulches can increase soil stability.
[Statement 6]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing on agricultural land has been shown to reduce runoff.
[Statement 7]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing on agricultural land can increase water filtration into the soil.
[Statement 8]: Ground cover in orchards and vineyards provides substantial erosion control.
[Statement 9]: Soils with ground cover experience less erosion compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 10]: Reducing grazing intensity helps prevent soil erosion.
[Statement 11]: Less sediment erosion occurs when grazing time in forage crops is reduced.
[Statement 12]: Buffer strips planted along water courses contribute to erosion control.
[Statement 13]: Grass buffer strips can decrease sediment in runoff from irrigated fields and pastures.

[Statement 1]: Soil amendment with manures and municipal wastes on agricultural land has several documented benefits and some drawbacks.
[Statement 2]: Manure amendments provide multiple soil benefits, including higher microbial biomass and respiration.
[Statement 3]: Manure amendments increase soil organic matter and create larger soil aggregations, which positively affects soil physical properties.
[Statement 4]: Manure amendments result in higher carbon levels in the soil.
[Statement 5]: Manure applications can reduce soil loss and water runoff when combined with other treatments.
[Statement 6]: Manure applications can lead to higher crop yields.
[Statement 7]: Manure applications improved soil stability in some comparisons.
[Statement 8]: Municipal compost applications greatly reduce soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid soils.
[Statement 9]: Manure additions increase nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium levels in soils compared to soils without manure.
[Statement 10]: Manure additions increase plant cover and the number of plant species.
[Statement 11]: Cotton gin compost and poultry manure applied at high rates improve soil structure.
[Statement 12]: Cotton gin compost and poultry manure applied at high rates reduce soil loss.
[Statement 13]: Mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments increase microbial biomass, activity, and diversity.
[Statement 14]: Mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments provide more organic carbon and nutrients to the soil.
[Statement 15]: Manure applications can cause higher nitrate leaching.
[Statement 16]: Increased nutrient loss can occur when cotton gin compost and poultry manure are applied at high rates.
[Statement 17]: Manure additions can cause higher greenhouse gas emissions, including increased carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide emissions.
[Statement 18]: More nitrate, ammonium, phosphorus, potassium, and organic matter leached from soils with added manure compared to soils without manure.
[Statement 19]: Municipal waste amendments showed mixed results in one trial.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__On agricultural land, what are the documented benefits and drawbacks of amending soil with manures or municipal wastes?
_claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils.
[Statement 2]: Amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains improves soil structure.
[Statement 3]: One study from India found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated.
[Statement 4]: Adding organic processing wastes or their composts also improves soil structure.
[Statement 5]: One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
[Statement 6]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments was found to be more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone.
[Statement 7]: Growing cover crops when a field is empty improves soil structure.
[Statement 8]: Three randomized, replicated studies found that growing cover crops improved soil structure, including higher soil porosity and interconnectivity and lower resistance.
[Statement 9]: Using a crop rotation that includes legumes increases water infiltration and improves soil structure.
[Statement 10]: Retaining crop residues provides mixed effects on soil physical properties including penetration resistance and the size of soil aggregates.
[Statement 11]: Changing tillage practices can improve soil structure.
[Statement 12]: Two studies found reduced compaction under controlled traffic.
[Statement 13]: One study found that crop yields increased under no-tillage.
[Statement 14]: Using reduced tillage results in soil aggregates having higher water-stability and more large aggregates in some comparisons.
[Statement 15]: Using no tillage instead of reduced tillage creates more large aggregates and higher water-stability in some comparisons.
[Statement 16]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing improves soil structure.
[Statement 17]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing creates a higher number of pores in the soil.
[Statement 18]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing results in less compaction.
[Statement 19]: Controlling traffic and traffic timing reduces runoff and increases water filtration into the soil.
[Statement 20]: Actions to improve soil structure have been tested on various soil types including clay and clay-loam soils specifically.
